name: Arawakan (> Southern Maipuran)
1_comment: external aspect marker "Imperfective aspect is expressed in Yine with the suffix -wa, which indicates that the event denoted by the predicate is ongoing and/or has not come to an end", "compatible with the completive suffix". Cf. a continuous (internal) aspect suffix -wa on p. 203
1_tam_restrictions: appears on verbal predicates, nonverbal predicates, direct objects

name: Arawakan (> Caribbean Arawakan)
1_tam_restrictions: without negation is possible only with locative words like 'there'

name: Tupian
2_comment: no special description, no examples without -ve

name: Pano-Tacanan
1_comment: “keep on / continue doing”, "an action is deliberately/voluntarily performed continuously"
2_comment: no special description, glossed as still but in examples more similar to already, compatible with finish

name: Quechuan
1_comment: "indicates continuity of action, state or quality", in combination with wh-words meaning is unclear
1_adjacent_meanings: despair ("how on Earth... "), once ~ first ~ not until, imminent future, but ~ while ~ whereas (contrast)

name: Cariban
1_meaning_under_negation_comment: not very clear examples but see p. 201 'don't live anymore', p. 177
1_adjacent_meanings_detailed: not very clear glossing but see p. 184

name: Nuclear-Macro-Je
2_meaning_under_negation_detailed: p. 152, ex. 15a; p. 198, ex. 75d; etc.; as an answer negation marker is omitted

name: Chibchan
1_comment: is not combined with tense marker (in contrast to completive and repetitive markers which are in complementary distribution with persistive); -i maybe analyzed as present tense marker; all examples are in present tense

name: Huitotoan
1_comment: no special description; a lot of not clear examples in texts; cf. a marker of pluractionality ("durative", p. 334) - does it have a continuative interpretation?

name: Matacoan
1_comment: "‘todavía, ya; ya no; antes de’. Puede anteponerse a un verbo o a un nombre. También puede ser predicativo."
2_comment: "‘todavía está/estaba hacienda algo"; no examples without negation

name: Arawan
1_comment: -kha is also a verb 'move, go', remoteness suffix in adverbs (p. 194)

name: Barbacoan
1_comment: borrowing from Spanish, no special description

name: Nambiquaran
1_comment: in most examples is ambigous with "in spite of"
2_comment: can be combined with other derivational suffixes

name: Chonan
1_comment: ambigous with progressive? not very clear description

name: Naduhup
1_tam_restrictions: predicates, predicate adjectives, predicate nominals (still night = morning)

name: Peba-Yagua
1_comment: "The formative -jancha 'continuous' means to do something without letting up or without stopping to rest"

name: Araucanian
1_adjacent_meanings: progressive (with perfective verbs? not clear); + neg = before
